### Prerequisites

- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Install PowerShell from Microsoft Store.
2. Run it as administrator.
3. Execute the following command: `Set-ExecutionPolicy Restricted -Scope LocalMachine`

### Expected behavior

```console
The execution policy for the LocalMachine scope is set to "Restricted".
```

To change the execution policy for the default (LocalMachine) scope, start PowerShell with the "Run as administrator" option. To change the execution policy for the current user, run "Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope CurrentUser".
```
```

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
@exchange12rocks Even though you may be an administrator, the error message would indicate you are not executing that command "as administrator".  If your machine has UAC enabled then even administrators run normally with a standard user token until they elevate a process.  Run PowerShell elevated (Run as Administrator) and then try that command - it should work.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5177512/143618860-79d1d6ee-e842-4587-8405-2e7bc9820d58.png)

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
@rkeithhill it’s more likely to be an issue with the permissions of that directory. It’s typically restricted to even administrators and is the reason why you run store app executables from an app exec link in your user profile. When Windows invokes an app exec link it modifies your access token with a special SID that allows you to access that directory and start the real executable. There’s a good chance that while it has read and execute permissions on that dir it doesnt have write needed for this operation.

That being said I could still be wrong, if your example was from pwsh installed from the store then this is not the problem.
